docs.lead_paragraph: GlaxoSmithKline said Thursday that it had signed a deal that could be worth up to $1.5 billion in payments and research funding for the biotechnology company ChemoCentryx to discover drugs. Glaxo said that ChemoCentryx would also receive an upfront payment of $63.5 million, made up of cash and an equity investment in the company.

headline.main: Glaxo in Deal To Develop New Drugs

docs.abstract: GlaxoSmithKline signs deal valued at up to $1.5 billion in payments and research funding for biotech company ChemcoCentryx to discover drugs; agreement is third signed by Glaxo's Center for Excellence for External Drug Discovery; collaboration covers number of projects for treatment of inflammatory disorders (M)

headline.main: 2 Studies Find High Weights Shorten Lives
headline.print_headline: 2 Studies Find High Weights Shorten Lives

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Modestly overweight baby boomers will live shorter lives, two studies will report tomorrow in The New England Journal of Medicine. That fits with the conventional wisdom of many public health experts who cite the increased risk of heart disease and cancer. But it runs counter to a study last year by researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the National Cancer Institute that found slightly overweight people had a somewhat lower risk of death.

headline.main: 2 Studies Find High Weights Shorten Lives

docs.abstract: Two studies conclude that modestly overweight baby boomers will live shorter lives; finding fits with conventional wisdom but runs counter to Centers for Disease Control study finding slightly overweight people have somewhat lower risk of death; one study looked at more than 500,000 AARP members over ten years; risk of death among women increased for any amount of extra weight; Dr Michael F Leitzmann of National Cancer Institute explains; second study in South Korea and at Johns Hopkins finds risk of death and cancer increases in people who are overweight but not obese (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The value of condoms goes far beyond disease prevention.

headline.main: Condoms Stay Faithful When Prevention Is the Goal
headline.print_headline: Condoms Stay Faithful When Prevention Is the Goal

docs.snippet: The value of condoms goes far beyond disease prevention.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a perfectly safe world, everyone who is not sexually abstinent would have sex with only one other person, who in turn is also monogamous for life. But, as we all know, the world is far from perfect. Most people have, in the course of their lives, more than one sexual partner. Hence, we have a worldwide epidemic of sexually transmitted diseases, and the most disastrous is AIDS. ''A condom can keep you from dying,'' said Dr. M. Monica Sweeney, author with Rita Kirwan Grisman of ''Condom Sense: A Guide to Sexual Survival in the New Millennium'' (Lantern Books, $10). ''The health of the world depends on condoms.''

headline.main: Condoms Stay Faithful When Prevention Is the Goal

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses importance of condom usage in preventing spread of AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases; says that consistent and correct usage of condoms is also as effective as birth control pills in preventing unwanted pregnancy and does not have any side effects or require prescription; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students explore the difference between hypochondriasis and somatization syndrome. Students also create scenarios and design experiments to learn about how behavior modification can curb stress in the daily lives of teens.
